overview: Child Benefit is a payment you'll get for each child until they reach 16, or 20 if they stay in education or training - what you'll get, eligibility and applying
title: Child Benefit

table.body:
You get Child Benefit if you're responsible for a child under 16 (or under 20 if they stay in education or training).

You get a tax-free payment for each child.

[Child Benefit rates](#what-youll-get "Child Benefit rates") are fixed till 2014. 

[Child Benefit stops](/when-child-benefit-stops "When Child Benefit stops") shortly after your child reaches 16 (or 20 if they stay in education or training).

You must report any [changes of circumstances](/changes-affect-child-benefit "Changes that affect Child Benefit") to the Child Benefit Office. 

%Only one person can claim Child Benefit for a child.%
table.title: Overview

table.body:
The current rates are in the table - these rates are fixed until April 2014.

Who the allowance is for |Rate (weekly) 
 - | - 
Eldest or only child |  £20.30
Additional children (per child) | £13.40
Guardian's Allowance (per child) | £14.75 

^[Guardian's Allowance](/guardians-allowance "Guardian's Allowance") is a benefit you could get if you're bringing up someone else's child - it's paid on top of Child Benefit.^

##How Child Benefit is paid
Child Benefit is paid into your bank account every 4 weeks. You can get it paid weekly if you're a single parent or getting certain other benefits, eg Income Support.
table.title: What you'll get

table.body:
%Only one person can claim Child Benefit for a child.% 

You normally qualify for Child Benefit if you're responsible for a child under 16 (or under 20 if they stay in education or training) and you live in the UK.

##16-19 year olds
You'll get [Child Benefit for 16-19 year olds](/changes-affect-child-benefit/16-19-year-olds "Child Benefits for 16-19 year olds") if they're in approved education or training. This includes GCSEs, A levels and NVQs (but not higher education, eg university) and government sponsored training programmes, eg apprenticeships. 

^Child Benefit continues for 20 weeks if 16 or 17 year olds leave education or training and register with the armed services or a government sponsored careers service.^

##Adoptions and fostering
You'll get Child Benefit if you're **not** receiving:

- payments towards accommodation
- basic maintenance from your local authority

##Living abroad
You could get Child Benefit if you're a national of an EEA country or Switzerland, and work in the UK (or get certain UK benefits, eg State Pension).

##New arrivals to the UK
You could get Child Benefit if your main home is now in the UK and you have permission to enter the UK and stay here.

^[Contact the Child Benefit Office](https://directgov-online.hmrc.gov.uk/shortforms/form/CBO_Specific?dept-name=CBO&sub-dept-name=General&location=3&origin=http://www.hmrc.gov.uk&lang=eng "Email the Child Benefit Office"){:rel="external"} if you have a question about your eligibility.^

*[EEA]: European Economic Area
table.title: Eligibility

table.body:
s1. Fill in a [Child Benefit claim form.](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/forms/ch2-online-stubb.htm "Child Benefit claim form"){:rel="external"}
s2. Send it to the Child Benefit Office with your child's original birth or adoption certificate.

$A
Child Benefit Office 
PO Box 1  
NE88 1AA
$A

Claim Child Benefit as soon as your child is born or comes to live with you.

Child Benefit can only be backdated for 3 months - make your claim as soon as possible.
table.title: How to claim

table.body:
##When Child Benefit payments stop
Child Benefit stops when your child reaches 16, or 20 if they stayed in education or training.

The payments stop on the first of these dates following their 16th or 20th birthday:

- the last day of February
- 31 May
- 31 August
- 30 November

%Child Benefit stops straightaway if your [circumstances change](/changes-affect-child-benefit "Changes that affect Child Benefit").%

##Child Benefit number
You can [find your Child Benefit number](/child-benefit-number "Finding your Child Benefit number") on any paperwork you have from the Child Benefit Office.

##Proof of Child Benefit
Use your Child Benefit award notice as proof of Child Benefit if you're asked for it (eg to claim free school meals).

You can provide other proof, eg:

- your latest tax credits award notice
- a bank statement showing your Child Benefit going into your account

^The Child Benefit Office doesn't provide written proof of your Child Benefit - you can use the documents listed above.^

##Changes of circumstances
You must report any [changes to your family life](/changes-affect-child-benefit "Changes that affect Child Benefit") (eg getting married) or to your child's life (eg leaving education) to the Child Benefit Office.

##Claiming Child Benefit for someone else
You can become an appointee to [manage someone else's Child Benefit claim.](/claim-child-benefit-behalf-someone-else "Claim Child Benefit on behalf of someone else")

##If your child isn't living with you
You could still claim Child Benefit if [your child isn't living with you,](/child-benefit-child-not-living-with-you "Child Benefit if your child doesn't live with you") eg is in hospital, in care, or is living with someone else some of the time.
